comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
The Times (London), Monday, Jul 04, 1904.
The early retirememt is announced of Captain Clay, of the steamship Scotia, the veteran commodore of the London and North-Western Railway Company's fine service of steamers between Holyhead and Dublin and Greenore. During his 31 years of command Captain Clay has navigated the Irish Sea 20,00 times, and has carried 1,250,000 passengers. He carried corn and flour to Ireland at the time of the great famine, and afterwards, at the time of the Crimean war, conveyed stores from Constantinople to Balaclava. He has saved many lives at sea.

comment._content: Captain Clay gave evidence at the inquiry, held at Liverpool, into the loss of the sailing ship Primrose Hill off Anglesey in December 1900.  At that time he was captain of the Holyhead and Dublin steamer Hibernia. (London Times April 3 1901).

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Suicide on the Scotia! The Times (London), Thursday, May 22, 1902
Captain Clay, of the London and North-Western passenger steamer Scotia, which reached the north wall from Holyhead at 7 o-clock this morning, has reported to the police that a gentleman named Healy jumped overboard when the vessel was within six miles of the Kish lightship. He sank at once, and though the ship was stopped and her starboard cutter searched in the vicinity for 35 minutes no trace of the body could be found. Several people witnessed the occurrence. The deceased gentleman, whose brother was travelling with him in the Scotia, is described as Dr. William Healy of Gower-street, London.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Huzzah for the long-serving Captain Clay! But was the London Times not a bit over enthusiastic about the length of service? Retired early in 1904 after 31 years = 1873-ish start to his service. They talk of the great famine (late 1840s) and the Crimean War (1850s)...

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: 1st SS Scotia1848 (479 tons)C & H Railway (L. & N. W. R. from 1859) Built by Wigram & Co 2nd SS Scotia Started on route in 1902(1872 tons) owned by L&NWR, Built by Lairds. It Survived service in WWI. Renamed Menevia in 1920 when new ship of the same name delivered. 3rd SS Scotia1921 (3441 tons) L&NWR, Built byDenny Bros. Sunk at Dunkirk on the 1st June 1940. Over 330 lives lost www.anglesey.info/holyhead_ships_history.htm

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: The Company was also building four new 21‐knot steamers for Dublin, bearing the traditional names Cambria, Hibernia, Anglia and Scotia. From Friday, 1st July 1898 the day service from North Wall was speeded up. One could leave North Wall at 10.15 a.m. and arrive in London at 8.45 p.m. From London the departure was at 11.00 a.m. and arrival at North Wall was at 8.30 p.m. (Irish time was still 25 minutes behind British time). .....................When the First World War broke out the Admiralty requisitioned the four express vessels, Anglia, Cambria, Hibernia and Scotia.......................SCOTIA. Details as Cambria....(Sister ship??) CAMBRIA. Built by Denny, Dumbarton. 329ft x 39ft, with a speed of 22 knots. The first of four passenger‐only express steamers bearing the traditional country names. All four requisitioned by the Admiralty in 1914, survived the War. Renamed Arvonia in 1920. Carried Free State troops and armoured cars from Dublin to Cork during the Irish Civil War. Relieved on various Irish Sea Routes. Scrapped 1925. www.thinkscape.ie/stenaline/holyhead_1561-2011.pdf

comment._content: A different Captain Clay (he obtained his rank in the British army) married Pauline Astor, who stood to inherit $100,000,000 in October 1904. That would certainly compel one to have an early retirement! Collier's Men and Events of the Year

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/mikeybrick] That bibliography has two entries for a Captain Clay:
Death Of Captain F.G. Clay Steamer Captain Holyhead 1919   page 171
and
Obituary Capt. T.G Clay Commodore Captain of LNWR Fleet Holyhead 1919 page 193

I assume that the first is the announcement of his death, and that the second is his obituary, and that (at least) one of them has misprinted his initials.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Looks like it was T G On Nov 2 1891 The Liverpool Mercury reported that
Mr. Thomas W. Clay, son of Captain T. G. Clay, of the L. and N. W. Railway Company's steamer Eleanor, passed his final examination for the triple qualification of the ROyal College of Physicians, Edinburgh, and faculty of SUrgeons, Glasgow; Mr David Lloyd Clay, another son of Captain Clay, passed his first professional examination for the Royal College of Physicians of London, and the Royal College of Surgeons of England
The North Wales Chronicle of Jan 9 1892 reported another suicide from the Dublin-Hoyhead ferry (the Eleanor), and mentions Captain T. G Clay. This suicide was "supposed to be a sailor under the influence of drink". The North Wales Chronicle April 22 1893 reports (untimely death klaxon)
DEATH AND FUNERAL OF MISS LILY CLAY - It is with the deepest regret we have this week to record the very sudden death of Lily Clay, second daughter of Captain T.G. Clay, of the London and North-Western Railway Company's express steamer "Rose". She was taken ill on Wednesday the 12th instant, and expired after only one day's ilness. The deceased was a faithful member of the English Presbyterian Chapel, Newry-street, and her loss will be deeply felt. The interment took place on Monday afternoon (amidst every sign of mourning throughout the town) at the Maeshyfryd Cemetery.
As well as Captain and Mrs Clay, it lists JR, TW, D Lloyd, John adn Dora as siblings of the deceased. I couldn't help noticing that beneath the account of the funeral and the long list of mourners, is a somewhat inappropriate 2-line advert
DON'T BE NERVOUS OR LOW-SPIRITED - Pepper's Quinine and Iron Tonic overcomes it entirely.
On Feb 3 1894 the North Wales Chronicle reported that The Royal Humane Society presented Captain T.G Clay a "beautilful illuminated address in recognition of his service in ordering out a boat to pick up the captain of this illfated steamer", the steamer in question being the "Captain Parry" of Dublin, which foundered some 12 or 13 miles west of the Skerries, with the loss of all crew apart from the captain.
